title: Swineshaw Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: michael ely / Pennine Bridleway, Higher Swineshaw Reservoir
images.caption: Pennine Bridleway, Higher Swineshaw Reservoir. Heading east along the dam wall of the reservoir. Higher Swineshaw Reservoir is the highest of four reservoirs in the Swineshaw Brook valley at about 300 metres above sea level.

images.title: andrew ringrose / Lower Swineshaw Reservoir
images.caption: Lower Swineshaw Reservoir. View SW over to Manchester.

images.title: Andy Stephenson / Upper Swineshaw Reservoir
images.caption: Upper Swineshaw Reservoir. Pennine Bridleway sign. Snow on the hills behind.

images.title: Bill Boaden / The south side of the Swineshaw valley
images.caption: The south side of the Swineshaw valley. This is the eastern ridge of Hollingworthall Moor. I am surprised that there are no sheep in this shot because the land is well grazed.

images.title: Roger May / Upper Swineshaw Reflections
images.caption: Upper Swineshaw Reflections. Just a light breeze ruffling the surface of the reservoir ripples its mirror-like quality on this bright, but chilly, November morning.

images.title: John Darch / Boar Flat
images.caption: Boar Flat. Higher Swineshaw Reservoir in the next square is in the middle distance.

description: Enjoy a circular walk around the Swineshaw Reservoirs on this route on the Pennine Moors. Start the walk from the car park at Walkerwood Reservoir on Brushes Road. You can then follow the Pennine Bridleway east past Brushes Reservoir to the Higher and Lower Swineshaw Reservoirs. The route then follows footpaths around the Lower Reservoir before climbing to Hollingworthall Moor. Other paths then descend back to Walkerwood and the car park. The reservoirs are located within the Stalybridge Country Park where there are more footpaths to try.
